image.altText: The back of a man's head is silhouetted against the glow of a bright computer screen.

items.synopsis: She thought it was a scam phone call, but it was a mother's worst nightmare, her daughter was an alleged victim of a paedophile child care worker.

title.children: How a piece of fabric helped police track down the man accused of 1,623 child abuse offences

image.altText: Murrandoo Yanner Jnr has short dark hair and a beard

items.synopsis: After numerous "once in a generation" disasters, a new summit suggests Indigenous expertise could help us better prepare for times of crisis.

title.children: 'They know this country': Push for First Nations knowledge-leaders to help guide natural disaster relief

image.altText: Lisa Evans and her daugther, both blonde and tanned, smiling in a photo.

items.synopsis: Breast cancer left Lisa Evans about $20,000 out of pocket, but the cost of monitoring her health continues. She is among patients and medical professionals who have contacted the ABC about concerns there is a gender bias in women's healthcare costs.

title.children: Lisa has found the cost of managing cancer 'debilitating'. For her brother, it was a different story

image.altText: Xi Jinping raises his glass and proposes a toast while standing behind a lecturn in front of Chinese flags.

items.synopsis: For much of the past 15 years, China has been developing a weapon that now has become increasingly unstable and that threatens to detonate from within, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: Turning Japanese: Why China could be heading for a fall

image.altText: Woman in white and black striped shirt wearing black hat standing on sand dune

items.synopsis: In remote far-western Queensland lies an ancient gorge, scattered with rock carvings, that's rarely visited. Traditional owners fear it could fall victim to the world's insatiable appetite for critical minerals.

title.children: 'We're an afterthought': Traditional owners fear repeat of Juukan Gorge disaster in outback Queensland

image.altText: Paul Smith grocery shopping in the vegetable section of the supermarket

items.synopsis: Ideal growing conditions this year have seen the volume of vegetables in one of Australia's largest winter production regions skyrocket, leading to oversupply and low farmgate prices.

title.children: Queensland farmers have grown too many vegetables, but who's to blame?

image.altText: A woman sits at a bench, with a shopping trolley.

items.synopsis: New data shows exactly how much the average cost of some of the most common grocery items have gone up and down in the last year. And the price tags on basic items, like canned tuna and beans, are among those increasing.

title.children: These are the everyday shoppers feeling the brunt of skyrocketing food prices

image.altText: Mugshot of a woman with blonde hair

items.synopsis: A judge sentences British nurse Lucy Letby to life in prison for murdering seven babies and attempting to kill six others in a neonatal ward in north-west England.

title.children: 'You have no remorse': British judge sentences baby-killing nurse to life in prison with no chance of parole

image.altText: A close up of James Hayward speaking to reporters.

items.synopsis: A sitting WA parliamentarian is on trial accused of sexually abusing a young girl, with prosecutors telling the court the MP admitted what he had "done" in a suicide email to his wife.

title.children: WA MP facing child sexual abuse charges sent wife 'suicide email' court hears

image.altText: A map of the world

items.synopsis: The Indian Ocean's version of El Niño — a positive Indian Ocean Dipole — typically brings a reduction in rainfall and an increase in temperatures through winter and spring.

title.children: Major weather event that influenced Black Summer bushfires rapidly forming near Australia

image.altText: Coles supermarket sign close up

items.synopsis: Supermarket and mining giants to report profit results today, amid high inflation and cost-of-living pressures. Follow live.

title.children: Coles, BHP and Woodside to report profits, ASX tipped to open higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Nasdaq: +1.56% to 13,497 points S & P500: +0.68% to 4,399 points Dow Jones: -0.11% to 34,463 points FTSE 100: -0.06% to 7,257 points Dax 30: +0.19% to 15,603 points Hang Seng: -1.82% to 17,623 points Spot gold: $1,893 Brent crude: $86.98 Iron ore: $100.91 Australian dollar: US$0.64c Bitcoin: $26,192
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Market snapshot at 7.45am AEST

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: BHP has set aside the first paragraph of its profit results to note the deaths of two colleagues during the year. It's a tragic reminder that nobody should be dying at work or suffering serious injuries. Its full year 2023 results: Full-year underlying profit: down 37% to $US13.4 billion Attributable profit after tax from total operations: down 58% to US$12.9 billion Revenue: down 17% to $US53.8 billion Underlying EBITDA: US$28 billion (-31%) The mining giant says its revenue decreased primarily as a result of significantly lower prices for iron ore, metallurgical coal, and copper. It says while it increased copper, iron ore and nickel sales volumes, and exchange rates were favourable, its profit from operations and EBITDA declined primarily due to lower commodity prices and the impacts of inflation on its cost base, particularly on labour, diesel and electricity prices. BHP shareholders will receive a full-year dividend of US$1.70 per share. The profit results were slightly weaker than analysts expected.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BHP profits down 37% on lower commodity prices

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, Australia's sharemarket is tipped to gain a little bit of ground in early trade this morning, according to ASX futures. Two of Wall Street's biggest exchanges finished in positive territory overnight. The Nasdaq closed +1.56% higher, to 13,497 points, and the S & P500 gained +0.68%, to 4,399 points. Locally, it's a busy day for profit reporting. Some of the companies reporting include: BHP (BHP) Coles Group (COL) Woodside Energy (WPL) ARB Corporation (ARB) Data#3 (DTL) HUB24 (HUB) Megaport Limited (MP1) Monash IVF (MVF) Nanosonics (NAN) Peter Warren Automotive (PWR) Redbubble (RBL) Silk Logistics Holdings (SLH) Wagners (WGN)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX tipped to gain some ground early

image.altText: Men's legs with rainbow socks and football boots

items.synopsis: Not a single elite male AFL player has ever come out publicly as gay or bisexual. This is what happened when Four Corners tried to ask about the silence.

title.children: We tried to tackle the AFL's last great taboo. The code got defensive

image.altText: A close shot of Brereton, who is sitting in the offices of the new national anti--corruption commission

items.synopsis: Finally a reality, the National Anti-Corruption Commission must now prove its worth. And that will be a test not of its design, nor of its powers. It will be a test of leadership, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: Will the new corruption body learn the lessons of the botched Robodebt investigation?

image.altText: President biden descends plane staircase with the first lady

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Biden arrives in Maui to survey wildfire damage — The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US President Joe Biden has arrived in Hawaii, where wildfires have left a trail of devastation. He and First Lady Jill Biden are meeting with first responders and receiving updates from state and local officials. They will then visit the devastated city of Lahaina to see the wildfire damage firsthand, talk with survivors, receive a briefing from state and local officials and deliver remarks. Mr Biden is also expected to pay tribute to the victims. The fires have killed more than 100 people in Hawaii.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Biden arrives in Maui nearly two weeks after fires

props.alt: President Joe Biden and first lady Jill Biden walking off plane.

children.content: US President Joe Biden has arrived in Hawaii, where wildfires have left a trail of devastation.
He and First Lady Jill Biden are meeting with first responders and receiving updates from state and local officials.
They will then visit the devastated city of Lahaina to see the wildfire damage firsthand, talk with survivors, receive a briefing from state and local officials and deliver remarks.
Mr Biden is also expected to pay tribute to the victims.
The fires have killed more than

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The clean-up has begun in some areas of California from Storm Hilary and it now moves to Nevada, Utah and into the north-west of the US. In Cathedral city, locals were forced to flee their homes in the middle of the night as large downpours led to flash flooding. Some residents of a care home had to be rescued with excavation equipment. Reuters is reporting the storm flooded streets and downed power lines across Southern California but no deaths have been recorded.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Pictures show aftermath of Tropical Storm Hilary in California

props.alt: A muddy, flooded street with damaged cars

children.content: The clean-up has begun in some areas of California from Storm Hilary and it now moves to Nevada, Utah and into the north-west of the US.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Russian mercenary chief Yevgeny Prigozhin has posted his first video address since leading a short-lived mutiny in late June. Prigozhin appears in a clip, possibly shot in Africa, on Telegram channels affiliated with the Wagner group. In the video, he is seen standing in a desert area in camouflage and with a rifle in his hands. In the distance, there are more armed men and a pickup truck. Reuters was not able to geolocate or verify the date of the video, but Prigozhin's comments and some posts in the pro-Wagner channels suggested it was filmed in Africa. "The temperature is +50 - everything as we like. The Wagner PMC makes Russia even greater on all continents, and Africa - more free. Justice and happiness - for the African people, we're making life a nightmare for ISIS and Al-Qaeda and other bandits," Prigozhin says in a video. He then says Wagner is recruiting people and the group "will fulfil the tasks that were set". The video is accompanied by a telephone number for those who want to join the group. The future of Wagner and Prigozhin has been unclear since he led a short mutiny against the Russian defence establishment in late June and the Kremlin said he and some of his fighters — who have fought in some of the fiercest battles of the Ukraine war — would leave for Belarus. Since the mutiny, some Wagner fighters have moved to Belarus and started training the army there. In comments published in late July, Prigozhin also says Wagner is ready to further increase its presence in Africa
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wagner chief hints at being in Africa in new video

props.alt: A man in camouflage outside on dirt holding a large gun

children.content: Russian mercenary chief Yevgeny Prigozhin has posted his first video address since leading a short-lived mutiny in late June.
Prigozhin appears in a clip, possibly shot in Africa, on Telegram channels affiliated with the Wagner group.
In the video, he is seen standing in a desert area in camouflage and with a rifle in his hands.
In the distance, there are more armed men and a pickup truck.
Reuters was not able to geolocate or verify the date of the video, but Prigozhin's comments and some posts in the pro-Wagner channels suggested it was filmed in Africa.

"The temperature is +50 - everything as we like. The Wagner PMC makes Russia even greater on all continents, and Africa - more free. Justice and happiness - for the African people, we're making life a nightmare for ISIS and Al-Qaeda and other bandits," Prigozhin says in a video.
He then says Wagner is recruiting people and the group "will fulfil the tasks that were set".
The video is accompanied by a telephone number for those who want to join the group.
The future of Wagner and Prigozhin has been unclear since he
against the Russian defence establishment in late June and the Kremlin said he and some of his fighters — who have fought in some of the fiercest battles of the Ukraine war — would leave for Belarus.
Since the mutiny, some Wagner fighters have moved to Belarus and started training the army there.
In comments published in late July, Prigozhin also says Wagner is ready to further increase its presence in Africa

image.altText: A grey and white image shows craters and ridges on the surface of the moon.

items.synopsis: India launched a moon rocket for less than the cost of a Hollywood space film and it's sent back new pictures of the far side of the lunar surface as it looks for a safe place to land.

title.children: Indian lunar rocket looking for safe landing place, systems working 'perfectly'

image.altText: Electricians place solar panels on roof

title.children: Is it worth investing in a battery for your rooftop solar? Here's what you need to know before you buy

image.altText: a mother and daughter at their dining table

title.children: Mum takes 'new slate' approach to booming estate where young residents remove 'blinkers' to mingle

image.altText: Woman on a swing with a billowing red dress

title.children: The pandemic made Alana turn to a 'higher power', but made others question their beliefs

title.children: The Aussie dollar could slump below 60 US cents, bringing with it pain and gain

image.altText: A smiling, older woman stands next a blossoming wisteria tree.

title.children: How Peter Dutton's policing career led to 'siege mentality' approach to parenting

image.altText: An aerial view of an outback city shows a green sports oval and red dirt with the mining stack on the horizon

title.children: In the days before Dio Kemp's death, her mother took her to hospital four times and to her GP twice

image.altText: A close-up of the Qantas logo on the tail of one of its planes. The sky behind it is clear.

title.children: Qantas hit with lawsuit for treating customers 'as providers of $1 billion in interest-free loans'

image.altText: A family of four with cows behind them.

items.synopsis: With neighbouring farms folding on Queensland's Scenic Rim, Kay and Dave Tommerup had to choose between closing or saving their fifth-generation dairy by radically changing how they did business.

title.children: Since cutting ties with its processor this dairy farm now makes four times as much
